So yeah, in Cleveland, they built this idea of community wealth building, which is essentially based on the idea that you attempt to kind of embed local capital by using the combined economic weight of what they call anchor institutions, so institutions that can't move, universities, public services like the NHS, local government, education, et cetera.  get them to come together to use their procurement budgets in order to prioritise local companies, get them to prioritise corporations that are unionised, that may be co-operatives, and bring that together with a load of other strategies aimed at boosting democratic, mutual, co-operative, collective ownership locally, and also doing things like setting up local banks. This very like neoliberal model of running a council, which is based on the idea that, you know, you should be outsourcing services, providing them as cheaply as possible and shrinking down the council, which can come to act as a kind of mediator between private interests rather than a provider of services itself.  And the kind of the classic idea of that is like Barnet, which came up with this idea of one council where capital was just kind of brought in to run everything.  And, you know, according to kind of the traditional neoclassical economic thinking on this, where these corporations are and who runs them shouldn't matter.  It's all about doing things as cheaply as possible.  So there's more capital to go around for everyone.
